image.altText: Three police officers standing around an Indigenous man in a wheelchair, at community markets.

props.synopsis: Body-worn video footage played to the Darwin Local Court captures a loud thud as an Aboriginal man with a disability is dropped into a police wagon, drawing an audible gasp from another officer.

title.children: NT police officer assaulted Aboriginal man in wheelchair, court rules

image.altText: A woman smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: A study will work with Indigenous researchers who will map cultural assets and integrate traditional healing to improve outcomes in remote centres.

title.children: Researcher wants First Nations suicide prevention put 'in our hands'

image.altText: A woman laughs in front of a boom mic

props.synopsis: Comments about Indian migrants were one thing, but refusing to back her leader made it impossible for the NT politician to stay.

title.children: Sacking Jacinta Nampijinpa Price was Opposition Leader's only option

image.altText: Politician looks ahead at press conference

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory chief minister is spending her first overseas trip spruiking the NT's ability to host hundreds of Japanese Self-Defense Force soldiers each year.

title.children: NT leader flies to Japan in bid to draw defence troops to Darwin

image.altText: People marching for NAIDOC Rally. One lady holds a sign that reads 'Treaty Now'.

props.synopsis: For Aboriginal people, it has been centuries in the making. As Victoria tables legislation for the country's first treaty with First Nations people, Indigenous leaders are urging other states and territories to follow suit.

title.children: First Nations leaders applaud Australia's first treaty centuries in the making

image.altText: A man with dark hair and a beard, standing with his arms crossed.

props.synopsis: Fifteen years after it was first earmarked for "pedestrian infrastructure", a 1 kilometre-long road in Darwin's north remains dangerously underdeveloped, according to residents and local politicians.

title.children: Urgent calls for overdue upgrades on dangerous Darwin road

image.altText: A small dinghy approaches a large fishing boat

props.synopsis: The Australian Border Force is launching a reporting function on a popular fishing app, but stakeholders in the far north say the technology means little without more boots on the ground.

title.children: Border Force turns to popular app to help fight illegal fishing

image.altText: A white land cruiser is smashed by a large tree that has been uprooted by wind

props.synopsis: Strong winds uprooted trees, with branches and entire trunks landing on cars and roads when a storm hit Alice Springs.

title.children: Residents clean up after surprise storm lashes Alice Springs

image.altText: Generic picture of Australian bank notes

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has told business leaders he is open to reforming the tax to boost investment in a "fair and affordable" way, but there is no agreement on a clear way forward.

title.children: Economists warn Labor has little hope of finding consensus on company tax

image.altText: Army personnel in khaki uniforms hold rifles and walk through a street littered with debris

props.synopsis: After days of deadly riots that killed at least 30 people, a relative calm has been restored in Kathmandu as the army begins negotiations with protest organisers over what happens next.

title.children: Police say 13,500 prisoners escaped custody during deadly Nepal riots

image.altText: Silhouette of a gamer's head as they play video games

props.synopsis: With gaming disorders estimated to affect hundreds of thousands nationwide, an Australian first clinic at Fiona Stanley Hospital is helping people who struggle to control their use to turn their lives around.

title.children: Gaming addiction 'devastates' families, but this clinic is helping them recover

image.altText: A man with short dark curly hair wearing a navy blue jacket and a light blue shirt.

props.synopsis: Australia's move to expand Woodside's North West Shelf gas project has not been welcomed in the Pacific, which is fighting the most dramatic effects of climate change.

title.children: Australia wants to expand a massive gas project but Pacific nations aren't happy

image.altText: Man has a serious expression as he sits in front of a radio microphone. He has shoulder length brown hair and wears a cap.

props.synopsis: When AFL player Mitch Brown openly came out as the first bisexual man in AFL history, he wasn't expecting the guilt that followed. While the 36-year-old has "no regrets", he admits he's disappointed by the lack of support from some within the AFL.

title.children: ‘I’ll walk with you’: Mitch Brown’s message to next queer AFL player

image.altText: A collapsed building with dirty flood water rushing past in West Denpasar, Bali.

props.synopsis: Bali has been rocked by unusual and deadly flooding as heavy rains inundate homes, major roads and force large evacuations.

title.children: At least eight dead in Bali floods

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: The local share market is set to drop when trading resumes. Meanwhile, Wall Street's S&P 500 has closed at record highs. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to drop after Wall Street's S&P 500 reaches record highs

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: US investors react to unexpected fall in inflation data
Household spending ticked higher last month: CBA
Home-buying dream pushed further away by RBA rate cuts

image.altText: About 10 men photographed holding signs protesting their work conditions

props.synopsis: Melbourne-based company Ansell has confirmed it investigated allegations at a Malaysian factory and identified issues that do not meet labour standards.

title.children: Australian glove-maker Ansell accused of exploiting workers

image.altText: Ange Postecoglou claps his hands after a Tottenham win in the Premier League.

props.synopsis: Nottingham Forest fans have been made a promise by Ange Postecoglou that he'll give his all to help them bring back their glory days.

title.children: 'I love winning things': Ange vows to take Forest back to the top

image.altText: A hand holds a smart phone, showing Jennie on an Instagram feed holding a lipstick.

props.synopsis: Once considered niche, K-beauty products are now everywhere — from luxury department stores to local pharmacies and even supermarkets. It is one of the fastest-growing sectors in the Australian cosmetics landscape.

title.children: How snail mucin, salmon sperm and 'glass skin' have lured skincare shoppers

image.altText: Incoming Wallabies head coach Les Kiss poses for a photograph in a stadium, holding a ball

props.synopsis: Incoming Wallabies coach Les Kiss has praised the Australian team for the "fantastic job" they have done in guiding them up the world rankings.

title.children: Next coach praises 'fantastic work' of resurgent Wallabies

image.altText: A man in a yellow shirt claps

props.synopsis: Two-time grand slam champion and Australia's Davis Cup captain Lleyton Hewitt has been suspended for two weeks for pushing an anti-doping official.

title.children: Lleyton Hewitt suspended for pushing anti-doping official

image.altText: Amir Maimon looks down on the Press Club stage.

props.synopsis: WA's premier refuses to say whether he raised war crime allegations with Israel's ambassador to Australia when the pair met, amid growing international concern about the provision of aid in Gaza.

title.children: Premier coy on whether alleged war crimes raised with Israel ambassador

image.altText: Joe Biden closes eyes as Kamala Harris hugs him on stage at rally

props.synopsis: In an excerpt from her forthcoming book, Kamala Harris says it was reckless to allow former US president Joe Biden to decide to seek re-election in 2024 but she felt she could not advise her boss not to run.

title.children: Harris says allowing Biden to seek re-election was 'recklessness'

image.altText: wide shot of hundreds of people gathered at night in a public square with the cuboid building lit in red.

props.synopsis: The frustrations with Nepal's government spill beyond the country's borders, with the diaspora in Australia taking to the streets to express solidarity.

title.children: Australia's Nepalese community backs anti-government protests

image.altText: A dry outback racecourse, with barriers looping the track, and mountains in the backdrop.

props.synopsis: In SA's Flinders Ranges ovals, golf courses and race tracks help people forget about drought for a brief time, even when they are also dry.

title.children: Dry and dusty sports clubs offer solace to drought-stricken towns

image.altText: Detective Superintendent Jason Kelly provides an update to media.

props.synopsis: Officers say the announcement of the reward over the weekend triggered a significant amount of information, but there are still no confirmed sightings of the alleged gunman.

title.children: Police combing through 200 tips after posting $1m Dezi Freeman reward

image.altText: Prince Harry waves as he enters a car in London.

props.synopsis: The prince has been in the UK for the past week amid speculation of a meeting with his father.

title.children: Prince Harry meets with King Charles during London visit

image.altText: An australian passport.

props.synopsis: While the number of passports and licences declared lost in the post only represents a very small proportion of the millions sent each year, identity theft experts have described the figures as "concerning".

title.children: Fraud warning issued as figures reveal scale of IDs reported 'lost in the post'

image.altText: Hazy photo of Chengdu skyline at sunset.

props.synopsis: Emissions from the 180 biggest carbon polluters directly contributed half of the total increase in heatwave intensity between the late 1800s and this century, a new study found.

title.children: Individual emitters triggered otherwise 'impossible' heatwaves: study

image.altText: Lotus Pavilion interior with rows of chairs, flowers on pillars outdoors

props.synopsis: With Sydney grappling with the need for more burial plots, the city's funeral industry is also presented with a new problem — a lack of open-air funeral venues.

title.children: The little-known Sydney funeral venue where bookings are hard to come by

image.altText: A masked protester holds a red flare in front of a statue during a demonstration in Paris.

props.synopsis: French police have used water canons and tear gas to break up "Block Everything" protests across the country, to demonstrate against President Emmanuel Macron, proposed budget cuts and the entire political class.

title.children: Almost 300 arrested in France amid 'Block Everything' protests

image.altText: Three people in a supermarket.

props.synopsis: Residents in a South Australian town will go to the polls to decide if the local supermarket can open Sundays and public holidays.

title.children: Country town to vote on allowing big supermarket to open Sundays

image.altText: A white electric ute in a green paddock with a trailer full of tree waste

props.synopsis: The Ford F150 Lightning is being touted as the first viable EV for farm work, but it comes with a hefty price tag.

title.children: New electric ute sparks interest on farms but diesel still dominates

image.altText: Torrie Lewis looks up at the end of a race wearing green and gold

props.synopsis: For Torrie Lewis, these World Athletics Championships in Tokyo are just the beginning of a journey she hopes will take her to very top of world sprinting.

title.children: Freeman. Pearson. Lewis? The giants inspiring our next sprint superstar

image.altText: A group of workshop staff stand together in front of tyre shelves

props.synopsis: Mount Isa is calling out for migrant workers despite recent anti-immigration marches across the country.

title.children: Outback Queensland mining town's door open to migrants

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black and white scarf looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian woman says she is prepared to be labelled as "stupid, naive, reckless" for her decision to join what organisers have described as a "civilian maritime mission organised to break Israel's illegal siege on Gaza".

title.children: Hobart mother joins Greta Thunberg in the Global Sumud Flotilla mission for Gaza
